_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, nurse tanks, shutoff valves, plumbing, hoses and liquid pump

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS FACILITY IS ONLY MANNED SEASONALLY.
The management and employees of Carroll Service Company are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of  anhydrous ammonia.  If an accident should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Thomson Fire Department, Carroll County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. The stationary source and the regulated substance handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 15080 Argo Fay Rte, Thomson, IL  is storage and sale to farmers.Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  The storage and handling system consists of two 30,000 gallon storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 510,000 pounds, this includes the amounf of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.

3. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPAÂ¿s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of Â¿Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1Â¿, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR1910.111, Â¿Storage and Handling of Anhydrous AmmoniaÂ¿.  Compliance with these  regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident program.

4. Five year accident history.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammo

nia in the past five years that:
-Have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor
-To our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6. The emergency response program.

The facility has:
-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38; 
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Thomson Fire Department and Carroll County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and the Carroll County LEPC.

7. Planned changes to improve safety.
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR  A NURSE TANK

The storage of an anhydrous ammonia nurse tank is 1,000 gallon.  The maximum pounds that can be stored is 4250 pounds.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident program.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
-Have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage

at the facility; nor
-To our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter inplace, property damage, or environmental damage.

The emergency response program.
The facility has:
-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Thomson Fire Department and Carroll County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and the Carroll County LEPC.

Planned changes to improve safety.
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.  In the off season there are no nurse tanks at this location.  The nurse tanks are stored at the east plant on Elkhorn Rd in Milledgeville.
